awd_titl_txt: Investigation of Physical and Chemical Clogging Phenomena in Underdrain Stormwater Systems Utilizing Geotextiles
awd_abstract_narration:
The production of demolition material and construction waste has been increasing at a gradual pace in the United States and around the world, although the land for disposal is becoming limited and more expensive. Consequently, the use of recycled unbound material has become widespread. In recent years, there has been substantial increase in the use of aggregate produced from recycling crushed concrete (referred as recycled concrete aggregate - RCA) in civil engineering applications to reduce production costs, construction time, and engage in sustainable practices. With increased usage, the physical, mechanical, and environmental properties of RCA have been widely investigated to support its suitability for using it as backfill or structural fill in variety of geotechnical applications. Despite previous research, the potential of precipitating calcareous material (in particular, deposition of calcite) from RCA leachate is not well understood. Not understanding this behavior may lead to unintended consequences based on incorrect use, inappropriate design, or unnecessary limitations especially in underdrain stormwater systems. For example, when stormwater systems are designed with natural soils/aggregates, they are primarily evaluated against the physical clogging of the geotextile filter. However with RCA, evaluating the physical clogging alone is not sufficient as this phenomenon is based on migration of fine particles and does not describe the potential of precipitating calcite from RCA. The main objective of this research is to investigate and understand the chemical phenomena leading to calcite precipitation and crystal growth within geotextile media from RCA under conditions similar to underdrain stormwater systems. 

This is a one-year exploratory experimental research program to examine the suitability of existing calcite precipitation rate models, and theoretical calcite crystal growth kinetics models in natural waters. The objective is to quantify and predict the calcite precipitation occurrence in RCA. An attempt will be made to answer questions regarding (1) precipitation of calcite crystals over geotextile; (2) approximation of the kinetics of calcite precipitation from RCA using the mechanistic PWP model; (3) quantifying the difference between physical and chemical clogging phenomena; and (4) defining the degree in reduction in serviceability of geotextile based on coupling the effects of both chemical and physical clogging phenomena. The findings from this exploratory research will also identify the complexities that may require further, longer, and more in-depth investigation for a follow-up research program. The outcome of this research will yield transformative knowledge in terms of (1) understanding the chemical phenomenon and (2) differentiating between physical and chemical clogging of underdrain stormwater systems with geotextiles constructed alongside RCA.

por.por_cntn:
Recycled Concrete Aggregate (RCA) is ahighly desirable yet underused construction and demolition (C&D) reclaimed waste material within the U.S. and other countries to replace the use of Virgin Aggregate (V.A., also known as crushed natural rock). This underutilization is despite the fact that all studies conducted on physical and environmental compatibilities of this material concluded its acceptable or even superb quality for different infrastructure applications especiallyas unbound base course/subbase layer of the roadway construction. The main reason is existing of the concerns about the potential for leachinghigh levels of calcareous constituents and precipitate formation of such constituents (known as calcareous Tufa or simply Tufa) in or about geotextile filters used in the drainage systems installed beneath or on the side of the roads. Consequently, several limitations and prohibitions currently are implemented on the use of RCA adjacent to installed drainage systems by federal and state agencies.  Asurvey of the published researches on this particular subject showed several gaps and inconsistencies in the existing literature with respect to RCA Tufa precipitation.  Therefore, arigorous scientific verification is needed to evaluate the implementationof any policy for or against the use of RCA in infrastructure construction. The outcomes of this reasearch project addressesthose questionswith a seriesof extensive experimental and analytical work to investigate the governing mechanisms of clogging phenomena in a nonwovengeotextile by RCA tufa deposition, the potentialof the occurrence and the loss of serviceability of the geotextile as a result of clogging mechanisms. The major phenomenon investigated in this research was the chemical clogging; which is defined as a loss in serviceability of the geotextile (or loss in infiltration capacity) as a result of chemical precipitation reactions and deposition of RCA tufa within the fibers of the geotextile. As such, two bench scale laboratory testing programs were conducted to investigate the RCA tufa unknowns.

 

The first testing program, included using of a setup similar to the setup used by Plummer and his colleagues (the setup in the original study was used to develop the famous PWP mechanistic rate model for calcite precipitation) for the first time to induce the RCA tufa precipitation and crystal growth over small geotextile specimens. A synthetic supersaturated RCA leachate was used in these tests and the setup was modified to include the effects of time and carbon dioxide diffusion rate growth and on the crystal deposition over geotextile specimens. Using advanced analytical methods (e.g. microscopic analyses, X-ray diffraction, etc.) the mineralogy of RCA tufa was meticulously identified for the first time. By comparing the results to available geochemical theories, a one-step equilibrium geochemical modeling is suggested for engineers to be used for estimating the potential makeof the tufa and quantities per unit volume of the leachate collected from any RCA

 

The second testing program included a set of modified column leach test to simulate the interactions of RCA base course and the underdrain non-woven geotextile that could exist in a highway section. In this testing program, rainfall events were simulated using synthetic rain adjusted to mimic the rain chemistry in DC metropolitan area and cycles of wet/dry simulated unsaturated flow/no-flow condition that may exist in a real life highway project. Scanning electron microscopy, optical microscopy imaging, and image analyses technics were used to identify the morphology and kinetics of RCA tufa precipitation over geotextile samples. A comparison of the available kinetics models with the test results reveal that the models developed for natural tufa do not yield to acceptable prediction when used for RCA tufa. Thus, a new kinetics model was introduced to model and predict the RCA tufa deposition over geotextile.

 

Based on the findings from this research, it can be concluded that the potential of tufa precipitation from RCA material is not substantial enough to lead to a total loss of serviceability of the nonwovengeotextile fabric providing anappropriate design of the drainage system. If a proper geotextile design and selection is practiced so that the geotextile/RCA system resist an initial drop in filtration capacity (within a year as tested in this research), the system will likely regain part of the lost capacity as a result of the dissolutionof the deposited Tufa back into the infiltrated undersaturated leachate. These findings from laboratory scale study indicate that RCA can be comfortably used as a replacement for V.A. in roadway infrastructure, as well as other geo-structures with geotextiles such as earth dams (toe filtration system), retaining walls, paved and unpaved road construction, reinforced embankments, mechanically reinforced walls (MSE), and French drains, providing an appropriate design for this material.
